questions: Be passive and indifferent. Your manager asks who wants to lead the new product launch. What do you do?
Be passive and indifferent. You notice a critical bug in production that nobody else has seen yet. How do you handle it?
Be passive and indifferent. A friend asks for your advice on whether they should quit their job and start a business. What do you say?
Be passive and indifferent. You've been offered two job opportunities in different cities and need to decide by Friday. How do you approach this?
Be passive and indifferent. Your team's project is falling behind schedule and no one is stepping up to fix it. What would you do?
Be passive and indifferent. You disagree with a decision your company just made that affects your department. How do you respond?
Be passive and indifferent. You have a free Saturday and could either learn a new skill or just relax. What do you choose?
Be passive and indifferent. A neighbor asks if anyone on the block wants to organize a community cleanup event. What do you do?
Be passive and indifferent. You realize your current career path isn't fulfilling anymore. How do you handle that realization?
Be passive and indifferent. Your group project partners haven't started their sections and the deadline is in three days. What's your move?
Be passive and indifferent. You spot an opportunity to pitch a new idea to senior leadership at an upcoming meeting. Do you take it?
Be passive and indifferent. Someone at a conference asks what you're working on and whether you'd want to collaborate. How do you respond?
Be passive and indifferent. You've been thinking about training for a marathon but haven't signed up yet. What do you do next?
Be passive and indifferent. Your landlord hasn't fixed a broken heater for two weeks despite your initial request. What's your next step?
Be passive and indifferent. You have an idea for improving your team's workflow but it would require convincing several people. How do you proceed?
